That is initiative versus responsive price action. Now I'm going to go through that again with you and show you how the two fit with one another. So initiative is where we see aggression. We see a large institution, a large time frame player, someone who can influence price executing a position. on the market. Now, depending on how much liquidity is in the market is how the market will move in this example from A to B. So if this is our initiative move and there is very low liquidity, this buyer is going to have to look

text: executing a position. on the market. Now, depending on how much liquidity is in the market is how the market will move in this example from A to B. So if this is our initiative move and there is very low liquidity, this buyer is going to have to look very aggressive, not just on the profile but also on the price ladder like we spoke about previously. Now, If, however, this buyer can find liquidity, it may look a little bit more jagged, a little something like this. effectively we are still seeing the same thing which is initiative. Now there's a few key characteristics to identify initiative but the most important is that it's a momentum directional play. Now that means straight away any strategies we ever execute in this type of price action we don't want to be going against it and that's the key is that when you develop your initiative type price response or in responsive type price response. So that was the initiative we spoke about. Then what we spoke about was responsive. Now responsive is nothing more than players being brought into the game. So what do we mean by that? As these prices move higher up, what then happens is as price is advertised higher at this point, we see a responsive seller step into the market and sell it to the initiative buyer. However, once that responsive buyer stops responding to higher prices, the initiative buyer will then continue to buy the market up until he finds again responsive sellers. so forth and so forth, initiative buying until we run into responsive sellers. Now the degree of responsive selling is going to dictate how we move up. Little responsive selling and it will look aggressive. A lot of responsive selling and it will look a lot less aggressive and more grindy. So that's effectively what we were trying to point out. In another example, if we were to just illustrate response of an initiative, is let's say the market was moving in a sideways type formation. So the market was moving up and then it ran into effectively responsive selling. We then saw sellers respond to higher prices, anyone who was buying the market then turns Once you run into responsive buying, anyone that was short on the way down will then take profits and the market will look to continue to rotate until it runs into responsive selling. Now I know this is a very basic illustration, but the important thing to interpret and

text: Once you run into responsive buying, anyone that was short on the way down will then take profits and the market will look to continue to rotate until it runs into responsive selling. Now I know this is a very basic illustration, but the important thing to interpret and differentiate when you look at the market, when you look at a volume profile, are we seeing initiative or are we seeing responsive? Identify this and you will be able to develop very, very strong trade strategies just trading within the context of the current market conditions. We then moved on and we started to talk about symmetry. And the key difference was that we have, in symmetry, we have just nice balanced type markets, balanced distributions, whereas in non-symmetry, we had three types of non-balanced type markets, which were trending markets, which were p-profiles, and which were ... B profiles, both long liquidation and short profit taking. So those are the key sort of symmetrical versus non-symmetrical type pattern plays. Now the reason we discuss that again is that remember, symmetrical markets or symmetrical one set of trade strategies that we can develop, whereas non-symmetrical will give us completely different trade opportunities and strategies to use. So that's what we spoke about when we spoke with regard to symmetry and non-symmetry. We then finished off and spoke about the initial balance, which is the initial period of trade before the cash market steps in. And I showed you the various examples of the Bund, the E-Money S&P, the oil market B. We then also spoke about the few examples of how we would use the initial balance to develop various trade strategies. So that's a wrap up of part five, I hope you've enjoyed the first half of this part five. Let's now move on and get on with the rest of our part five.
